Posts.Content: I don't drink beer (or anything alcoholic, unless it's a tasty cocktail), but my husband loves Hobgoblin!
Posts.Title: Raising a glass to everyone going through treatment

Posts.Content: Thanks! It's great to see there is life beyond chemo! :-) And Cruella is a fab costume! Tomorrow is my anniversary; crappy timing with just having had chemo yesterday, but on the up side unless I have some horrible reaction to Tax I will be in great shape for Christmas, which is my favourite holiday anyway (yes, more than my anniversary, sssh :-P) Best of luck with the weight loss! You HAVE done amazingly! xx
Posts.Title: Raising a glass to everyone going through treatment

Posts.Content: That's insane that you can't get a mortgage! The stuff we don't know we need to think about...
Posts.Title: 5 years all clear

Posts.Content: Damn, I hope my hubby can come to my future appointments! He was SUCH a help. The only other person with a companion was another girl whose first treatment it was, too. No one has said anything about him being allowed or not, so I am just going to show up with him next time. I really needed him to help me take my mind off it.
Posts.Title: tv advert

Posts.Content: Whooohooooooo! Go you! What a great feeling it must be! I'll be on here in January with a similar post, can't wait! I hope everything is straightforward and easy from now on! xx
Posts.Title: Finished Chemo !!!

Posts.Content: I have a question - is the sore mouth on tax different to the sore mouth from FEC? My FEC mouth has been like I burned the skin off inside my mouth (like when you eat too much salt & vinegar flavoured stuff), along with a few mouth sores and cracking corners. I know others have it much worse! Is the Tax sore mouth similar or totally different?
Posts.Title: TAX - Sore Mouth - What to Eat?

Posts.Content: I'm just handling what I feel up to. Luckily I don't have children, so I don't have anybody to take care of but me - I am full of HUGE admiration for the mums who do this! If I don't feel like cooking, it's frozen microwave meals! Lay on a store in the freezer. Or something easy like a pie that can just be bought, put in the oven, and removed when done. The chemo guys gave me a bottle of hand sanitiser to keep in my handbag, and I just use that every time I go out and touch anything like a railing or a cash machine. Other than that, I'm staying in as much as possible. After my first FEC, I craved all sorts of odd things, so I had my husband buy them all in readiness for FEC 2, which was awesome. I went nuts for Waitrose organic sausages - the skinny "chipolata" ones with 12 in a pack. I made him buy 3 packs and cook all 36 at once, so I could snack on them whenever I wanted over those first few days. Broccoli, haloumi cheese, kiwi fruit, and baby potatoes smothered in butter and parsley were some other cravings! I think you just have to keep telling yourself that it's okay if you don't feel like doing anything. Don't feel guilty!
Posts.Title: Chemo advise please ?

Posts.Content: I feel your pain, hairworries - I have incredibly fine, thin hair, and it's never been shorter than just below the chin because I know how stupid I look with short hair. (I have big ears to make the look even better!). I started chemo last week and cut my hair as short as I could first, while still being long enough to tie back. I went with the cold cap, which felt pretty crappy, but obviously not TOO bad as I got through it. I think it was a Paxman because I remember at some point making a joke about Jeremy Paxman on University Challenge. I have to say, even though I'm going to continue with the cold cap, after just one treatment my priorities have changed. I felt really sick that first night and I've been so tired ever since, that now I'm all, "Who cares about my hair, I just want to feel well again!" Also the faint silver lining is that it's winter, so wigs won't be as hot or uncomfortable (hopefully), and we can even wear hats over our thinning hair and have it look passable. But I do know how you feel - my hair grows incredibly slowly too, so it'll take years to get back to "normal". I guess you just have to do what you can to fight off the evil cancer! It sucks. *hugs*
Posts.Title: CMF OR FEC WITH A COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: I waited well over a week for my "bad news". I thought they were most likely going to tell me it was just a non-cancerous lump, like my sister and mother had both had, so I wasn't even that worried. Good thing I wasn't, or that week would have been much more horrible! But they certainly didn't seem to try and rush it or anything. That might actually have scared me more.
Posts.Title: Average time for results?

Posts.Content: All cleeeear! Yeeeehaaaaa!
Posts.Title: Average time for results?

Posts.Content: And I bet fried egg sandwiches aren't even something you normally love or have a lot! I forgot that I ate a lot of boiled eggs, too, in the first week after chemo. The first FEC I think I ate a toasted cheese sandwich every night for a week (as a late night snack!). But I think I overdid it because I didn't want it after FEC 2 at all! But all my other cravings were the same. xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Hi Anne, Just wanted to say I hope you're feeling better today, and that you weren't sick! If you were, get Emend next time - it stopped me being sick the second time! Other than that, just relax and eat whatever you feel like. :-) I'm a big believer in your body telling you what it wants. I craved things I don't normally even think about wanting particularly. Now I know what to buy for next time. Sausages, broccoli, courgettes, haloumi cheese, avocado, kiwi fruit, and fish and chips with tons of lemon and vinegar!
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Well you've all convinced me! Since you can't find a bad word to say about a PICC line I'd better get one next time. :-) I think it really is just the idea of having something permanently in my body that freaks me out. (Well, semi-permanently).
Posts.Title: picc lines

Posts.Content: The chemo nurse at my first chemo last week was trying to encourage me to get a PICC line put in, but the idea really freaks me out, having that thing in my body all the time! I'm not worried about needles and I just feel like it'd be easier and simpler to get a new cannula done every time I have chemo, and have it taken out and go home clean, as it were. Is the picc really that much better an idea?
Posts.Title: picc lines

Posts.Content: Hello all! Quick update - It's 9 days since my first FEC and I'm feeling hugely better, aside from still feeling a bit tired. So yay! HOWever, my skin has gone to hell! I've always been prone to pimples around my chin and mouth area, and when I was disagnosed (I'm 35) I had to stop taking my contraceptive pill, which made my skin go a bit haywire over the following weeks. Right after the chemo, it suddenly cleared up, and I was thrilled at an actual good side effect! I thought the chemo must have dried it all out or done something good to the hormones. But that didn't last more than 3 days, and now I'm just a mass of pimples, so many so that it actually hurts a little when I move my mouth! Is this a common side effect, and is there anything I can take or put on them to help them along their way? I don't think I even had them this bad when I was in high school! I've always found with my skin that washing as seldom as possible with a light Dove soap is the best thing, but clearly this regimen is no match for chemo drugs! Any ideas? Thanksxx
Posts.Title: My skin is terrible!

Posts.Content: Yay, well done JuJu! I love reading about people coming through the other side happily and well! I must look into this Manuka honey - can you get it in supermarkets or health shops or where? I had a mouth ulcer before my first chemo; one of those annoying ones that I kept accidentally biting in my sleep and making worse! And then the chemo made it even more sore, and I STILL have it.
Posts.Title: Last chemo done, 3 x FEC and 3 x Taxatere. Done! finito!!

Posts.Content: Up days and down days - I've never been pregnant, but I'm thinking it feels a bit like that! I'm mentally ok one day and then the next day I'm just all, "I haaaaate this, life suuuuucks!". And it's scary being in that in between place, not knowing (especially as if they got her lump removal wrong, her confidence must be pretty knocked!). Add to that the physical symptoms of treatment (again, it's like flu and pregnancy cravings combined over here!), and it's no wonder she feels crappy. But she's lucky to have a sister like you looking for a support network for her. xx
Posts.Title: breast cancer newbie

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome! I'm a semi-newbie too (Just had my 2nd chemo last Wed), and everyone here is super nice and helpful!
Posts.Title: breast cancer newbie

Posts.Content: Hi Rosiero! Mine is also Invasive ductal carcinoma with ER5 and PR3 (still trying to figure out what that all actually means!). They gave me the choice of chemo or surgery first, and said it wouldnt matter which way round I did it, but I had to do both. I went for chemo because it could shrink the lump, and then the surgery should hopefully be less invasive? Like you, they say the breast should be fine and I won't need a full mastectomy. But I have to see what happens with the lymph nodes - the surgeon said we would try to save them, and the oncologist said they'd have to come out! So I don't know. I really wish I could have just had surgery to take out the cancer, and not had to go through chemo for ages, but whatever works best to save my life, I guess! *hugs*
Posts.Title: Another newbi

Posts.Content: Oh gosh, thank you! I don't even know if that got explained to me originally, but I certainly didn't retain it! The surgeon who broke the cancer news to me literally wrote it down on a piece of paper so I would know what I had, and it's still sitting by my computer. Thank you! xx
Posts.Title: Another newbi

Posts.Content: Hooray! I still have my eyebrows, but they have always been light and thin, so I'm hoping if I do lose them I won't look too different to normal! :-)
Posts.Title: An exciting day!

Posts.Content: I remember nearly a year ago I met up with a friend who had had chemo (also for BC). I hadn't seen her during her treatment, as she had it in France, and when I saw her I couldn't figure out why she looked slightly odd - she'd lost her hair, of course, but she was wearing a chic hat and looking all chic and French, as they do! It was only later on that I realised it was her lack of eyelashes that had made her look different. Tiny little things that you don't even notice until they're not there!
Posts.Title: An exciting day!

Posts.Content: How crappy, though - just when you thought you'd finished! I'd be pretty miserable about that. Be strong! *internet hugs*
Posts.Title: Undergoing chemo twice!
